name: Alspach's conjecture
rephrased: Every complete graph with n vertices and a set of cycle lengths summing to n has a disjoint cycle cover consisting exactly of cycles of those specified lengths.
implication_form: If a complete graph K_n has a multiset of cycle lengths C_1, C_2, ..., C_k such that C_1 + C_2 + ... + C_k = n, then K_n has a disjoint cycle cover consisting of cycles of lengths C_1, C_2, ..., C_k.
solved_by: Darryn Bryant, Daniel Horsley, and William Pettersson
explained: Alspach's conjecture states that for any complete graph K_n (where n is the number of vertices), and any partition of the integers from 1 to n-1 into parts each of which is the length of a cycle (or a set of cycles) that satisfy certain conditions, there exists a decomposition of the edges of K_n into edge-disjoint cycles whose lengths correspond exactly to the parts of the partition.
related_conjectures: Existence of cycle decompositions in graph theory
